docs.lead_paragraph: That Valentine's box of delectable chocolates that made your heart sing last weekend also might -- if it is the right type -- help make it tick better and longer, scientists gathered last week in Washington said. Raw cocoa contains flavonoids, plant-based compounds with protective antioxidants like those in green tea. The antioxidants, which may help decrease blood pressure and improve circulation, according to preliminary study results released at a daylong session centered on the medical uses and developmental potential of the cocoa tree.

headline.main: Beyond Delicious, Chocolate May Help Pump Up Your Heart

docs.abstract: Washington (DC) seminar on possible health benefits of chocolate is held by National Academy of Sciences and sponsored by Fogarty International Center of National Institutes of Health, University of California, Smithsonian and Mars, chocolate company; Dr Norman K Hollenberg, Brigham and Women's Hospital professor, presents research on Kuna Indians of San Blas islands, Panama, that links cocoa consumption and blood pressure; study finds that blood pressure of Indians increases when ingestion of natural source cocoa is reduced; several studies on positive effects of certain types of chocolate products, including Mars Cocoapro beverage, discussed; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: That Valentine's box of delectable chocolates that made your heart sing last weekend also might -- if it is the right type -- help make it tick better and longer, scientists gathered last week in Washington said.    Raw cocoa contains flavonoids,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Shrode can't sleep. At night, in the fly-speck town of Guthrie, Ky., in the rented farmhouse he shares with his 20-year-old wife, Debra, he surfs the Internet, roams the house. He lies down and gets up again. He drinks a beer and stares out the window at the black fields beyond. Hours pass. He can't sleep. Before the war, he could have six beers and sleep like a baby, but now that works against him. Drinking may help get his head to the pillow, but it also ratchets up the nightmares. For a while, he sweated out his bad dreams on the living-room couch, and it drove Debra crazy. She would come down from the bedroom, touch his shoulder, ask what the problem was. Shrode would just turn his back to her and not say a word. Now she knows better than to ask, though occasionally when the silence between them gets too deep, she'll put it out there, What're you thinking about?
docs.abstract: Sara Corbett article on physical and mental pain of American soldiers who have returned home after being injured in Iraq; notes they live in confounding mix of anonymity and exposure wrought by surviving war; soldiers attending support group at Fort Campbell, on Kentucky-Tennessee border, first on Army base for injured soldiers, comment; photos (M)
